articles.title: Apple Loses Title of World's Most Valuable Company as China Tariffs Loom
articles.content: Apple lost its title as the world's most valuable public company on Tuesday after the stock slid the day before steep tariffs on Chinese imports were scheduled to go into effect.

articles.title: Cellphones, clothes, TVs, toys: This is all the stuff the U.S. buys from China
articles.content: Cellphones, clothes, TVs, toys: This is all the stuff the U.S. buys from China

articles.title: Video: What Tariffs Will Do to Your iPhone
articles.content: President Trump’s tariffs aim to bring manufacturing back to the U.S.—including iPhones. WSJ’s Joanna Stern breaks down exactly how tough it would be to build iPhones here, and how tariffs could affect the price of your next phone.

articles.title: Apple Cedes Most-Valuable Crown After Tariff Pain Hits Stock Price
articles.content: How much has President Trump’s tariff plan cost Apple?  It is no longer the world’s most valuable company.  Apple’s shares fell 5% for the day and are now down 23% since last week’s tariff announcement.

articles.title: Apple Stock Falls After Getting Two Negative Reports
articles.content: Apple stock continued its brutal slide on Tuesday. It has lost 23% of its value over the past four trading sessions.

articles.title: These Stocks Moved the Most Today: Apple, Nvidia, Broadcom, Humana, CVS, Tesla, Super Micro, Marvell, and More
articles.content: Apple stock rises after a three-day stretch that has seen shares of the iPhone maker tumble 19%, Broadcom announces a new buyback program of $10 billion, and Humana, CVS Health, and UnitedHealth jump as Medicare boosts payment rates.

articles.title: Wedbush Cuts Apple, Tesla Targets as Tariff Pressure Mounts
articles.content: Wedbush cut Apple's price target to $250, citing tariff-related supply chain exposure.

articles.title: US Stock Futures Soar as Dip Buyers Emerge After Selloff
articles.content: (Bloomberg) -- US stocks rallied in premarket trading after a three-day selloff that wiped out more than $5 trillion of value in US equities. articles.title: Why We Don’t Have a Made-in-America iPhone
articles.content: President Trump’s tariffs aim to bring manufacturing back to the U.S.—including iPhones. WSJ’s Joanna Stern breaks down exactly how tough it would be to build iPhones here, and how tariffs could affect the price of your next phone.

articles.title: Apple Exported More Than $17 Billion of iPhones From India Last Year
articles.content: Apple exported more than $17 billion of iPhones from India last year, a rapid expansion that is set to help the company offset new tariffs announced by the Trump administration.  India’s smartphone exports jumped by more than 50% in the 12 months that ended in March compared to the previous year, the country’s technology minister said Tuesday.  The Wall Street Journal reported Monday that Apple plans to send more iPhones to the U.S. from India to offset the high cost of China tariffs.
